Entry Question: Updated HubSpot FTP for the New Design Manager
Response:
What is it?

HubSpot’s FTP has been updated for the new design manager. The new tool now gives you complete control over the folder and file structure of the design manager in your local environment.

Why does it matter?

FTP lets you transfer HTML files, CSS stylesheets, Javascript files, and file manager assets between HubSpot and your local development environment. Today’s updates to our FTP gives the CMS Developer the same file and folder management system they get within the design manager in their local environment. This gives them more flexibility and control over their workflow as they create assets in HubSpot. Best of all, the new FTP service also lets you create modules on the new module framework.

How does it work?

In the old FTP, you had access to folders that held your files within the file manager, the coded templates, and your custom modules. You could only access these files in the folder structure present within the design manager, and there was no way to edit folders outside of this structure. Today’s update adds a new root folder called “designs.”

Clicking into this folder, you will see the same file and folder view that is available in the new design manager. From here you’ll be able to manage all your HubSpot coded files. You can freely move files around, and easily create new directories.

With the new FTP, you can also create or delete new modules and see these changes reflected in the design manager --- something that was not possible in the old FTP.

Who gets it?

This is currently available to all Marketing Hub Basic, Professional, and Enterprise users that are in the new Design Manager.

Entry Question: HubSpot Video Optimization
Response:
What is it:

We will now display the file size and streaming rate of videos hosted within HubSpot File Manager. More importantly, videos uploaded to HubSpot File Manager will now automatically be optimized to stream on their website, and load quickly.

Why it matters:

Speed. One second can be the difference in a visitor staying on your site, or looking elsewhere. Serving videos that are good quality, but don’t sacrifice speed is a crucial aspect of user experience and how visitors will see your brand. As a content platform, many customers have enjoyed the ability to host video files of any size on HubSpot. But it’s come at the sacrifice of speed on their website. In addition, many CMSes today limit the size of a video you can upload, or don’t have the ability to upload videos at all.

  • WordPress: 8Mb upload (default), and up to 15 Mbs with customization
  • Weebly: 1Gb on uploads
  • Wix: No direct file size limitations, but charges for additional bandwidth between 30 minutes - 5 hours per month.
  • SquareSpace: No ability to upload a video directly. Must use a video hosting service.

When compared to video hosting services (YouTube, Vimeo, Wistia, etc.) most allow streaming bitrates ranged from 5Mb - 10Mb per second and are ideal for higher quality videos being streamed.

How is this being rolled-out?

Starting today all new video files uploaded directly to HubSpot File Manager will automatically be transcoded to stream at 2.5Mb per second. Customers will not need to do any additional work for this to happen -- it will automatically be done for them. If they would like to achieve a higher streaming rate, video’s should be uploaded to one of the video hosting services (Wistia, YouTube, Vimeo, etc.) and embedded within content in HubSpot. In addition, we will soon begin the process to convert any existing videos that exceed this limit and utilize video transcoding (optimization) to bring the streaming rate within 2.5Mb per second.

How do I know if a video exceeds 2.5Mb streaming?

The best method to determine the bitrate of a video is to preview the file within File Manager. We’ve added the Mb/s details to all video files in the file manager and any that are over the limit will display a link to download the original file immediately below:

There are 3,561 portals that have videos that exceed the limit. Here is a list of all portals, and files.

What can my customer do if they have a video that exceeds 2.5Mb/sec?

In the background, HubSpot File Manager will automatically optimize videos so they are at, or under, the limit of 2.5Mb per second. Customers can view or download these optimized files from File Manager.

If a customer is not happy with the optimized file, the original source file will be available within File Manager. If they want to utilize the original file it can be downloaded from HubSpot and then uploaded into a video hosting provider -- such as YouTube, or Wistia, and integrated with their content.

Why are we making this change?

As stated above, speed is crucial to a great user experience today and this change is one-step to help ensure content hosted on HubSpot loads very fast. In addition, from an internal cost savings perspective, this limit is estimated to save HubSpot $500,000 per year in hosting fees.

Entry Question: Why won't the image in my File Manager replace the current image in my content?
Response:
Be sure to check the name of the file:

Try using hyphens rather than an underscore or space when naming files, as underscores are interpreted as their own character by search engines and spaces are replaced with “%20", rendering file names hard to read. It is also recommended to stay away from the characters \ / : * ? ” < > | [ ] & $, as issues can arise between different operating systems; for instance, Mac allows certain symbols that Windows does not.

Source: https://blog.hubspot.com/customers/naming-convention-for-hubspot-file-manager

Entry Question: Updates To How We Handle Images and Links Within The Rich Text Editor
Response:
What is it?

The links plugin within the rich text editor has been updated to support different link types. The image plugin has also been updated to allow for easier editing.

Why does it matter?

Inserting a link into your text seems pretty straightforward, but you have a number of different options to choose from when doing so. You could add a “mailto:” link for an email address, a link for a telephone number, a link to a HubSpot hosted page or an external page, or a file download. The new links plugin takes out the hassle and manual editing we used to require when adding links by providing you with a number of predetermined link types for you to choose from.

The new images plugin gives you greater flexibility and more options when editing your images. Realize midway through editing an image that you chose the wrong one? Not a problem. With the new image plugin, you can replace an image and still have all your old styling applied to the new one, saving you time when editing your content.

How does it work?

When in the rich text editor, highlight a piece of content and click the links plugin. The new popover will ask you to select one of five link types: URL, File, Email, Phone number, or one of your pages.

Based on your selection, you’ll be given a relevant next step for that link type. For example, if you want to insert a file like a PDF, you’ll be asked to insert a file into the text.

For the image plugin, when you click on an image in a rich text module, you’ll be given the option to replace, remove, or edit the image. Clicking “options,” a tabbed editing window will appear. On the content tab, you can swap the image out, and easily add alt-text to your image. When swapping out an image, you now have the option to search for and add stock images from Shutterstock, directly from the image picker. On the style tab, you can edit the dimensions of your image, the alignment of the image, and add padding around the image. On the link tab, you can quickly hyperlink the image using the same links plugin described above.

Who gets it?

This is currently in beta. Pending feedback, it will soon be available to all Marketing Hub Starter, Basic, Professional, and Enterprise users.

Entry Question: Content Search
Response:
What is it?

Content search is the find-anything solution to engaging and providing helpful content to site visitors. Content search will index all content hosted on HubSpot.

 

Why is it important?

On April 1st, 2018, Google will be deprecating their site search. Currently, the alternative is to transition to Google Custom Search. Google Custom Search is a free option, that includes Google branding, and searches the entire internet for results, instead of just your website. This is obviously not an ideal solution for users looking to maintain full control over their site content.

 

HubSpot’s content search lets users quickly add a search field to any page, and index all of their HubSpot hosted content so that site visitors can quickly find whatever they are looking for.

 

How does it work?

Content search consists of 3 parts; the search field module (where a visitor inputs their search), the search results module, and the results systems template. To get started, create a ‘Search Results Page’ System template within the Design Manager.

 

The created template will include two new modules: Search Field and Search Results.



Once you’ve added your styling and other components to the page, you can manage which Search Results Page is used across your HubSpot hosted content by going to Settings > Web Pages > System Pages. You can then leverage the Search Field, or Search Results modules across other parts of your website. For example, you could add the Search Field module to your global header so it lives next to your site’s main navigation. When searching, the search field module will show up to three live suggestions for related results. Once you press enter, you will be brought to the full results page.

 

To see a live example of Content Search, check out designers.hubspot.com.

 

Note: The modules and template included in content search will not automatically match your template styles. It will take some development work to enable content search, and have it match the rest of a your website.

 

Who gets it?

This feature is currently in an open beta. If you have a customer who would like access to this beta, have them fill out this form. It’s important to note that users must have the new Design Manager in order to have Content Search.

 

What language is it in?

All languages supported by HubSpot

Entry Question: A Smarter (see: AI-powered) Recommended Content Module in the CMS
Response:
What is it

A new module in the CMS that, through the power of artificial intelligence, shows visitors to your blog the posts that'll be most relevant and interesting to them.

 

Why it matters

Inbound is all about being helpful to your buyers at every step of their journey. To be the most helpful, you need to serve them the right content for them. Something that’s relevant, timely, and new.

 

The new recommended posts module uses AI to determine which blog content will be most relevant, and displays only those posts to the reader. Think: the most popular post they haven’t seen, or a post about a topic they’re interested, or one by an author that they’ve frequented.

 

The result: a much better experience for your website visitors, with no extra work for you. Plus, as an added bonus, the new module won’t just surface your brand new posts; it’ll recommend the post that’s most relevant, even if it’s from the past. That means a longer lifespan for your content, and more sustainable traffic growth over time. Long story short, with the new module, everybody wins.

 

How it works

Navigate to the Design Manager, and edit any of your templates. Add a module, then swap that module for a Post Listing module by clicking the gear on the right-hand-side, then “Swap Module.”

 

 

Once your post listing module is in place, click the gear once again, and “Edit Options.”

 

Configure your module however you’d like, and choose “Recommended” under “List Posts by.”

 

 

Click “Done,” then save your template, and you’ll have a brand new module on your blog.

 

What does the future hold

The good news: the new module provides a more personalized experience for your website visitors. The even better news: because the recommended posts module leverages machine learning, it’ll get even smarter over time. As HubSpot’s systems learn your visitors’ habits and patterns, the posts we recommend will get even more personalized to their specific profile. Pretty awesome, right?

 

Who gets it

Today, a small group of beta Marketing Hub customers. Once live, the new recommended posts module will be available to all Marketing Hub customers.

FAQs:

Q: For first-time visitors, how does the recommended module decide which posts to show given there's not much context/info about the visitor yet?

A: For brand new visitors, the recommendations are influenced by the current piece of content. Brand new visitors are likely to see things like the most popular post in the same topic cluster, the most popular post by the same author, the post with the most shared views, or the most popular post overall.

Entry Question: Where do the validation metrics in the content strategy tool come from?
Response:
In the content strategy tool, there are four pieces of data that contribute to the topic validation for your subtopics and core topics. This data comes from a combination of various sources: 

  • Domain authority is calculated using Moz and is a prediction of how well a website will rank on search engines. It's measured on a logarithmic scale of 100 points.
  • Monthly search volume is calculated using SEMrush and is the average monthly searches for a keyword in search engines.
  • Relevancy is calculated using HubSpot propriety machine learning and measures the similarity of your topic to your existing content you have on any page with the HubSpot tracking code, on a scale of 0 to 100%. The higher your percentage, the closer you are to creating content that's relevant to what your existing content is known for.  
    • For example, a core topic of inbound marketing on HubSpot.com would be very relevant, whereas a topic about Siberian Huskies would likely not be very relevant to content we have written. Since the goal is to expand your area of influence, you likely want to have your relevancy score between 50% and 70%, but higher is perfectly fine as well.
  • Core topic similarity (subtopics only) is calculated using HubSpot propriety machine learning and measures the similarity of your subtopic to your core topic on a scale of 0 to 100%. The higher your percentage, the more closely related your subtopic is to your core topic.  

Note: 
- Relevancy is based on any page with the HubSpot tracking code and is NOT limited to HubSpot hosted content. Some of the messaging on the Wiki currently says this number comes from just hosted content which is misleading. 

- Domain Authority is based on the target domain set under Report Settings. This is important when considering multiple domains in a single enterprise portal.

Entry Question: Can we migrate website themes?
Response:
I just came across a migration of an empty theme.  It included all the various options for page layouts, but no actual website content for the customer.  At present, we don't offer migrations of themes for a few reasons (read below for more background).  They can have a Template Setup, but it will not include the various page layouts from their external theme.

Reasons we avoid theme migrations right now:

1) There isn't enough context for us to know what types of modules to use and whether the content they plan to put there will actually work or not.  This can give a sense of false hope abut just what's possible.

2) There's a lot of extras in there the customer will never use- it's not a good investment of our migration resources and they take up a great deal of time (tons of layouts and lots of Custom Modules).  When a customer builds out their staging site on an external theme, they pare down to the layouts they actually intend to use and that's a better time for us to get involved.

3) Legally, it's a fuzzy line.  We're toying with some ideas around this and the marketplace, but aren't able to move forward on them just yet.  If policy changes, we'll certainly let everyone know.

4) It's most often requested from partners wanting free design work, and they sometimes pass a bill (for work they don't do) onto the customer.  

5) And finally... they take a great deal of time to go live and reap the benefits, if they ever do.  They're similar to our issue with partial migrations, particularly when free of cost.  At that point, there is little to no investment from the customer and once they realize how much work is involved post-migration, some abandon the project all together.  We'd like to better focus our resources on good fit migrations that can go live and start HubSpotting right away.

A theme migration isn't quite the same as a staging website.  If you come across a staging website that has some placeholders but the majority is filled out with the customer's content, you can approve those.  Please ensure you add the "No URL Mappings" note, and a note about it being a staging website and further work being the responsibility of the customer and/or partner is helpful (we'll see about adding a default one for easy use).

Entry Question: Import any blog into HubSpot
Response:
How does it work?

It requires setting a few manual variables specific to the blog to turn into an XML file, in the form of CSS selectors, to find elements (title, meta D, post body, featured image, author, tags, publish date, etc.) on each post of a blog. These elements content are found for every post, and are then converted into XML elements exactly as our importer is expecting, and spits out a blog.xml file, ready for import into HubSpot! See the README.md 

Whats next? 

This tool is not ready to be communicated publicly as a solution for importing content into HubSpot at the moment, but it does work well. I would love to get it into the hands of the migration techs whom perform the manual migrations, to see if it could work on the types of blogs they are importing. Bugs need to be exposed and it needs to handle variance and errors better. 

What is the future of this tool/the concept of generating XML files for customers, rather than relying on third party softwares exports? 

I think a tool like this has potential to be a huge win for HubSpot - it opens up importing blogs (more successfully or at all) to a huge group of customers and prospective customers. This means more customers using our blog platform, and more satisfied, ever important, first touch HubSpot software experiences. Ideally, this tool would have UI, helping users find the selectors they need for hubXml to find content with. Maybe we could even find these selectors ourselves. 

I think I have a good prospective user for hubXml, what do I do?

Frankly, this tool is a little too raw to tell customers about as a solution for importing content into HubSpot at the moment, but...

hubXml is a Java program, so if you have an environment to run Java locally, you simply need to set a few variables as noted in the README to run this and generate an XML file. It works well, but I have only tested it on a few blogs. If you find/see bugs or room for improvement, please let me know or file an issue. 

What are some downsides of a tool like this?

The first that comes to mind is it is someones job to manually migrate posts right now. I care about these workers and their livelihood. Maybe the increase in sales/migrations from the availability of a tool like this would give them enough replacement template setup work. 

Second, is that once we say we can generate XML files, they better work. Just was I get angry with Wordpress when they export malformed XML to our new customers, if we set the expectation we can generate the XML file for them, we better deliver. 

Check it out: https://github.com/williamspiro/hubXml

Entry Question: When to use "Blog will be managed in blog module" vs. "Use the Blog Import Tool"
Response:
Along these lines, if you come across blog content or content that can easily be converted into a blog, please specify this in the notes. Please do not assume the technicians will migrate it without any direction. For this purpose, there are two separate notes:

Blog will be managed in blog module
This should be used for any blog content that needs to be manually migrated. Unless there is only one blog on the domain that is titled "blog", it is highly recommend that you specify the blog content within this note (add a link using the markup or just add the URL to the note).

If a customer has a WP blog and there is no indication that to the technicians to manually migrate it, they will leave it for import instead.

Use the Blog Import tool
This is for standard WP blogs and you can even attempt it on other blog platforms that produce an XML export. Even if a customer has already imported their posts, I'd recommend using this note and adjusting it accordingly. I also would recommend double-checking that the import was successful and spot-checking a post or two in the Edit mode to ensure all features transferred over (they may not all be visible in the blog layout until our technicians create a new one). The reason being is that many blogs "successfully" import, but they import with errors or custom WP features excluded. Those are not marked as failures in most cases. The XML output from different versions of WP can vary quite a lot, and many WP blogs are using custom featured images that do not always transfer.

It's also a good idea to check through their external blog for any content that may require it to be manually migrated (for instance; audio players, distinct forms on the sidebars or other content outside of the post itself that varies, like Related Posts).

You may find you also need to use a combination of the two notes above. I had one the other day where the blog could be easily imported, but they had portfolio content that we had to create as a custom blog. That is allowed, but if you use both notes, you definitely need to specify the content that will be impacted in either of them!

Speed matters. A slow-loading post can cause visitors to give-up and search elsewhere for information, or not convert on your site. Entry Question: A New Way to Preview Your Emails
Response:
What is it?

An all new way to preview and share your drafted emails, and ensure that your email looks as expected across a variety of screen sizes and email clients.

Why does it matter?

When creating marketing emails within HubSpot, it’s important to ensure not only that all internal stakeholders are happy with what you are sending, but that your email looks great no matter what device or email client the end-recipient will be viewing it on. This is because different email clients have their own rules regarding how they render marketing emails. In the old tool, there was no easy way to see how your email rendered across different email clients unless you personally used that client, and you could check it through sending a test email. This update gives you more options for previewing your emails within HubSpot so you can ensure you are satisfied with the end result.

How does it work?

Within the new email editor, you’ll now see a “preview” button located in the sub-nav at the top right hand corner of the email editor.

Clicking this button, you’ll be brought to the new preview modal. The preview modal includes two tabs --- devices and clients. On the devices tab, you’ll be able to preview your email on a desktop, or on a mobile device. You’ll also be able to preview the email as a specific contact. Marketing Hub Professional or Enterprise customers can also generate a shareable link of this preview.

On the clients tab (only available to Marketing Hub Professional or Enterprise users), you’ll be able to preview how your email will render across a long list of email clients. The top ten email clients are pre-selected, but you can also go through the long list of available email clients to determine which client is important for you to preview. Entry Question: Improved Email Deliverability Protection
Response:
What is it?

A number of improvements have been made to how we handle deliverability of Marketing Emails at the list and portal level within HubSpot.

 

List-level: We’re now using a machine learning model to predict the bounce rate of a list when it’s imported into HubSpot.

 

Portal-level: We’re adding in-app messaging and sending alerts to CSMs so we can proactively educate customers on best email practices.

 

Why does it matter?

Inbound Marketing centers around providing helpful and relevant content to your customers at every stage of their buying journey. The goal here is to build trust and credibility for your brand. Strong deliverability is at the core of the Inbound email-marketing playbook. It doesn’t matter how good the content of your email is if you can’t get it into the inbox of your target audience in the first place.

 

These updates are important for two key reasons:

 

  1. We’re better able to educate customers on best email practices in a proactive manner, while also protecting HubSpot’s world-class deliverability.

  2. We’re able to prevent bad lists from damaging a customer’s sending reputation, even before an email is sent.

 

How does it work?

 

List Level:

HubSpot has a wealth of data and information for the majority of contacts in any given list import. We’ll run this data through a new machine learning model to predict the list’s average hard bounce rate. If we predict a hard bounce rate above an egregiously-high threshold, we’ll notify customers and take action to protect our network -- including quarantining lists. Check out this wiki to learn more about what these notifications look like for our customers.

 

We’re being very conservative to start, beginning only with imports that have a predicted hard bounce rate significantly higher than the email industry average. We’ll tweak that over time and introduce new actions and messaging as we scale email marketing to lower price points.

 

Portal Level:
Within the Email dashboard and notification center, we’ll provide customers with messaging such as the one below.

 

Please see this wiki post for full details on how the messaging will work.

 

TLDR -- there are 3 portal “states” that represent increasingly high thresholds: Warning, Penalty, and Pre-Suspension. Each portal state will have a corresponding in-app banner that will provide actionable resources so they can improve their deliverability.

 

Internally, we’ve created a Portal States section in Auxilium that will let Support or CSMs quickly see why a portal has been warned or penalized (e.g. hard bounce rate), allowing you to take the appropriate action with a customer.

 

We’re also notifying CSMs via Salesforce alerts when their customer’s email performance has dropped significantly within the past 30 days. This will equip CSMs to proactively reach out to their customers with helpful tips to improve their email marketing.

You’re a HubSpot customer with an important Marketing Email campaign that has to get out.

Entry Question: Whitelist & Unbounce Wizard
Response:
What is it:

An in-app wizard to guide users through the process of whitelisting HubSpot IP addresses if internal email recipients are bouncing.

Why it matters:  

Customers (especially new ones) will sometimes find that emails and notifications sent from HubSpot to internal contacts at the same company don’t get delivered. Why? If you're using a third party service like HubSpot, and then use your company's domain name as the 'from' address to send an email to a colleague at the same domain (e.g. from: bill@yourcompanyname.com to bob@yourcompanyname.com), then: - Your company's mail server sees an email coming from a HubSpot server - This email claims to be from your company's domain - Your company's mail server knows it’s not coming from there and rejects it since it suspects spoofing

The solution is to whitelist HubSpot IP addresses to ensure that these messages get delivered.

Until now, this has been a source of confusion for customers, and subsequently a big call driver for Support. The new wizard will play a huge role in alleviating the need for these calls by pointing people to the resolution and unbouncing contacts from actions taken within the app.

  1. First, you’re directed to the knowledge article that explains in more detail why emails bounce.

  1. The wizard prompts you to add HubSpot to your whitelist and links out to the knowledge doc containing the correct IP addresses to whitelist. It also provides a draft email to send to an IT department with the error messages returned from your server.

  1. Finally, you'll see the option to send a test email to one of the bounced contacts to make sure emails are getting through. In the background, these contacts are unbounced before the test is sent.

Entry Question: Smart Timezone Sending for Emails
Response:
What is it:

Customers can now schedule emails to send based on their recipients timezone. By scheduling with the ‘Smart Send’ option - you can now ensure all your recipients receive the email on a scheduled date and time, no matter what timezone they are in.

After the email is scheduled, the user will see a new Smart sending tab on the performance page. This tab shows email performance based on GMT offsets as shown below.

How does Smart Timezone Sending know when to deliver an email?

For contacts that have previously opened or clicked on an email, we store their IP location information as contact properties (IP Country & IP Country Code). At send time we use this location information to group email sends into GMT offsets. If no location information exists for a contact, we will default to the portals timezone (which displays as ‘Unknown’ in email reporting).

Why it matters:

For marketers that have international presence, delivering email at a time that’s relevant to them improves open rates, click rates, and overall brand perception. Emails delivered at odd hours, such as really late at night or very early in the morning often get ignored or immediately discarded. With Smart Timezone sending Marketing Mary can easily schedule an email to be delivered in multiple timezones, all with one-click.

Entry Question: Graymail Suppression for Contacts with Low Engagement
Response:
Introducing Graymail Suppression
As your inbound engine runs at full speed and your database steadily grows, it’s critical to make sure that you’re keeping the quality of your email lists high. Although the size of your lists might be getting more impressive over time, it’s much more important to pay attention to the number of contacts who are actually engaging with your emails.
 
Here’s why: continually emailing contacts who don’t engage with your emails can actually hurt the deliverability of all your messages, even to contacts who do want to hear from you. This type of email activity to contacts with low engagement is called graymail.
 
Today, we’re making it very simple to avoid sending graymail. When choosing recipients in the email editor, you will now see a list of contacts with low engagement that you have the option to exclude from your send. We've also introduced a new “sends since last engagement” contact property (which can be used for segmentation in Lists and Workflows). Use these two features in conjunction to capitalize on your existing audience and improve their email experience.
 
How it works
When preparing your email to send, you’ll see a new checkbox on the recipients tab labeled “Don’t send to contacts with low engagement.” This feature relies on an automatically generated list of contacts who haven’t opened more than the last 10 emails you’ve sent them. Leaving this checkbox selected will exclude these contacts from your send.
 
After your send, you’ll see a confirmation on the email performance screen, reminding you that some contacts were excluded via graymail suppression.
 
 
By default, the graymail suppression checkbox is enabled for all of your sends moving forward. If you want to change this behavior and have graymail suppression turned off by default, you can do so by visiting Content > Content Settings > Email Settings. At the bottom of the settings screen, you’ll find an option to change the default.
 
 
Now available to all HubSpot customers
Graymail suppression is now available to all HubSpot customers. You can share this post from product updates about Graymail Suppression, or check it out by creating a new email campaign.

Entry Question: Deliverability Protection
Response:
What is it?

Deliverability Protection is a new safeguard inside HubSpot Email that protects our customers’ email reputation & deliverability by detecting and stopping sends with an abnormally high bounce rate.

Why is it important

Maintaining high deliverability rates is a key part of an effective email strategy. Email campaigns that have a very high hard bounce rate can have a substantial negative impact on deliverability. By detecting this when it starts to happen, HubSpot can prevent further damage to sender scores in real time.

How it Works

Deliverability Protection works by first sending a portion of an email campaign, gauging the hard bounce rate, and stopping sends that incur a hard bounce rate of more than 15% before the remainder of the campaign goes out. (This process happens quickly - over the course of a few minutes - so most customers won't notice a delay.)

What happens when a send is stopped?

When an email send has stopped, HubSpot will send each affected customer an automatic email to let them know this has happened.


In addition to the email, on the post-send screen in app, an affected customer will see a banner that informs them that the message has stopped processing. Clicking “Learn More” opens up a modal with more details.


Who gets it?

deliverability Protection is currently in BETA. When it rolls out fully, it will be available to all HubSpot customers.


FAQ:

  • are we able to see in the last 30 days which customers have exceeded this threshold, or how often do we find customers in that group of high bouncers?
  • After the customer has completed the remediation steps recommended, are they safe to resend the email again? I assume that would involve cloning and resending, correct? If so, would we need to go through the process of creating a list of anyone who was previously sent the email and adding it as an exclusion list, so that recipients don't receive dupes?
    • Jeff Russo response: 

      Kevin and I caught up on this. While there isn't a way to see who has exceeded this threshold today, it's something that it may make sense for us to provide in the future. To add some context, a customer hitting the threshold of a 15% hard bounce rate happens pretty infrequently, so we aren't expecting this to come as a surprise to many customers once it rolls out. We will communicate what this is in the notification center and through some of our other customer channels to give folks some context about it.

      One other thing worth noting that a few folks asked - if a customer's send is stopped, we aren't doing anything to prevent them from their next send - so, if a customer created a new list (maybe a lis that excluded any contacts they thought might be low quality / causing the issue) they would be able to immediately retry their send. (They could also theoretically retry the same list, though they would likely see the same result.)

Entry Question: Email Deliverability Lunch & Learn
Response:
Meeting Minutes

Content: Watch
Deck: SE Deliverability Deck
Presenter: Evan Murphy 
Slack: @evan
Email: emurphy@hubspot.com

Why use an Email Service Provider?

  • Shared email servers are great for low volume or infrequent senders
  • By using shared servers HubSpot co-signs our customers email with our high deliverability reputation
  • Each portal is in a “swim lane” that can be contained and rerouted in the event of a deliverability outage or if another customer causes a block

Infrastructure:

  • Tripped thresholds creates a case in SFDC, we will engage the customer if it happens repeatedly (3+ times)
  • We measure reputation by sender score, but remember that this is an aggregate measure of all our customers
    • Our sender score is maintained in the high 90s
  • 12 IPs per swim lane, 10 lanes, hundreds of customers per lane
    • MTAs: 
      • Sendgrid: Our original sending system
      • Franklin: Our in-house sending system
      • SparkPost: Third sending system for reliability
    • having multiple MTAs protects against disaster recovery if one of them goes down

Email Add-ons

  • Dedicated IP for marketing email ($500/mo)
    • Implementation involves setting up 5 DNS records
  • Transactional Email ($1000/mo)
    • Email sent using this system excludes an Unsubscribe link
    • Email copy can’t have commercial intent whatsoever
    • Includes a dedicated IP for all transactional email
    • Includes API and SMTP relay integration access
    • Customers can route receipts, order confirmations or other emails from their external systems through HubSpot to gain email analytics on the contact timeline

Purchased Lists & Our ToS

  • We clearly say customers cannot send to purchased lists and must abide by industry best practices; not all our competitors have this
    • Malicious Intent = customers willing to harm other shared resources
    • Moving to a dedicated IP reduces risk of harming other customers, but will not fix deliverability issues created by bad email practices
    • It's reasonable for us to improve a customer's deliverability if they are willing to change their behavior, but simply switching to HubSpot or to a dedicated IP will not be enough
      • When customers move from tool to tool and don't change their behavior, it will actually cause more harm to their reputation (than if they stayed put) 

Dedicated vs Shared IP:

  • Shared IP
    • Portal is in a swim lane that consists of 4 IPs
    • With authentication (email domains set up) - requires 3 CNAMEs 
      • 1 for SPF - gives HubSpot permission to send from the customer's domain
      • 2 for DKIM - hosts a public key we can use to encrypt the message, until it is decrypted by the receiving inbox; this prevents malicious sources from tampering with the message during transmission, as any changes would break the key
      • email headers will still show HubSpot, would need dedicated IP to completely white-label
    • Spam reports and excessive hard bounces impact everyone
    • We have minimum acceptable thresholds for Hard Bounce (5%) and Spam Report (0.1%) rates, if a portal exceeds them there are reactive systems behind-the-scenes:
      • Email Protection
      • Send-level Email Protection may stop an email send if it exceeds these thresholds; notifies the customer
      • Portal-level Email Protection may impose penalties like slower sending; notifies the CSM using Salesforce Alerts
  • Dedicated IP 
    • Good reasons to sell a dedicated IP
      • The customer wants a white labeled solution
      • We remove any mention of HubSpot from the infrastructure for more consistent branding
      • Good for large brands or industries where elevated trust is required
      • The customer sends more than 100k/monthly
      • This can be waived– the key is consistency
      • The customer mentions DMARC, SPF or DKIM
      • Advanced email technical requirements our shared infrastructure may not support
    • Bad reasons to sell a dedicated IP 
      • For marketing email
        • If a customer only wants it temporarily or for a specific campaign or lead source
        • To bypass a rule in our Acceptable Use Policy
        • To “get around hard bounces” - surprise! Same rules apply
        • To “fix” an existing deliverability issue
      • For transactional email
        • To “get around unsubscribes”
        • To send marketing email without an unsubscribe
    • they get their own server, own reputation
    • completely white-labeled
    • great for risk-intolerant verticals like government, education, and security/IT that are more likely to have stricter inbox security measures
    • can sell to a customer sending less than 100k emails/month if they are consistent senders (should still be sending at least 15k-20k emails/month)

Bounce Policy:

  • Global Bounces -- 3x3x60 -- if we see the same email address bounce 3 times in 3 separate portals within 60 days, the address will be globally bounced from all portals
  • Hard: permanent reason (address does not exist), will never be able to deliver to this address
  • Soft: temporary reason (full inbox, server busy), may be able to deliver in the future
  • Marketing Email Health Score: provides insight into the key statistics that contribute to a healthy email reputation. The average customer score is a 75 -- https://wiki.hubspotcentral.net/display/emaildeliverability/Marketing+Email+Health+Score

Deliverability Concepts:

I guarantee high deliverability if you...

  • Have verifiable permission from recipients before sending them email from HubSpot
  • Use double opt-in to confirm email address ownership for each new recipient
  • Monitor hard bounce, spam report and unsubscribe rates for downward trends
  • Conduct a re-engagement campaign at least every 90 days
  • Define a cut-off point after which unengaged subscribers are suppressed
  • Have re-subscription enabled for HubSpot forms in case those subscribers come back again organically

Opt-in for Marketing Email:

Types of opt-in/consent for marketing email

  • Express: he user takes an action to give permission, e.g. by choosing a checkbox during sign up or confirming their subscription by clicking a link via email
  • Implied: email given for a business purpose, e.g. through a “contact us” form or to gain access to a gated resource
  • None: purchased lists, publicly available email addresses, a list of all attendees from a trade show, conference or webinar

Origin, Opt-in, Expectation: Trust as a framework

  • Origin: How was the relationship with these contacts established?
  • Opt-in: What kind of permission or consent did they provide to you?
  • Expectation: Does the content they’re receiving align with what they were told when they signed up?
  • Conduct a source audit
    • Take inventory of your customers lead conversion paths, evaluate the level of opt-in for each source, and maintain a record for future use
    • In the event of deliverability issues you can refer to the list as you evaluate their performance statistics - where do you find concentrations in lead source?
    • These sources are often the most actionable for strategic changes

Getting Help

We partner with you to investigate, diagnose and remediate deliverability issues but you are a liaison between your customer and Email Deliverability:

Start in #support-email Slack channel
Emergency? Send us an email:

emaildeliverability@hubspot.com

Entry Question: All Marketing Hub trials now include email
Response:
What is it?

All Marketing Hub trials now have access to the email tool.

 

Why is it important?

1) It rids us of an incredibly manual and painful process. Before this update, prospects and customers had to explicitly request a trial of email, Sales had to fill out an additional request form and vet the customer, and the Deliverability team had to approve and manage these trials to mitigate the risk to HubSpot’s deliverability. There was also some negotiating of trial parameters, which doesn’t scale well.

 

2) It solves for the customer. Testing out the HubSpot email tool is an important part of the trial process for prospective customers - and our prospects really want to try email. In a recent test of free users, interest in marketing email drove 2.5x more PQLs than other products.

 

3) Our protection technology is stronger than it's ever been. Since trials were first established for the email tool, the Email Protection team has come a long way in terms of automating abuse prevention and introducing predictive actions. Entry Question: Retina support for CTAs
Response:
What is it?

CTAs now support retina optimization, making images used within them CTAs more crisp.

 

Why does it matter?

CTAs allow you to create dynamic, personalized buttons to move your site visitors or email recipients from one page to the next, and track that activity. Supporting retina images ensures that CTAs appear just as clear as any other asset on your website. This update takes care of a long-standing feature request.

 

How does it work?

CTAs created within HubSpot will now automatically support retina rendering where applicable (see note below). There is no action needed for our customers to enable this. This update leveraging image resizing functionality inside File Manager and a html attribute known as srcset.

 

 

Technical Note

This is supported when a customer uploads an image that is at least 2 times the size necessary for the CTA, similarly to how retina support works for all images across the net. If the user is creating a CTA that will be 400px by 100px, the image that is uploaded would need to be 800px by 200px to support an @2x pixel density display. CTAs support adding up to a 4x version, in this case uploading a 1600px by 400px image, and the CTA will automatically be rendered on the customer’s website with a srcset attribute serving the 1x, 2x, 3x and 4x version where available.

 

If the image is uploaded at the size the CTA will be rendered at (i.e. a 400px by 100px image is uploaded for a 400px by 100px CTA), this will not have retina support.

 

This is automatically applied to all image-based CTAs that were originally uploaded at at least 2x the size of the CTA, and applies to all existing and newly created button-based CTAs. If a customer notices that their image based CTA is not retina optimized, they will have to re-upload the CTA image to meet the technical specifications.

 

Email Support?

This new scrset attribute is also applied to CTAs used in emails, and works for modern versions of Apple Mail and iOS mail but does not work for other email clients such as Outlook or webmail services like Gmail.

 

Who gets it?

We will be slowly rolling this out to select portals with applicable CTAs over the next week. It will be available to all Marketing Basic, Professional, and Enterprise customers in the new CTAs Beta UI within the coming weeks.

Entry Question: Advanced Attribution Reporting
Response:
What is it?

Members of the ads add-on beta group now have access to multiple attribution reports on their campaigns dashboard, enabling them to see exactly how their ads are influencing their customers at every stage of their buying journey.

Why does it matter?

Measurement is one of the main pillars of journey-based advertising. That’s because the goal of any advertising campaign you run should be to generate a positive return on your investment. But as your customers move through their buyer’s journey, you’ll want to use your advertising to drive different objectives. For example,

  • If your ads are focused on in the awareness stage of the buyer’s journey, you’ll want to see which ads are driving people’s first visits to your website, how many of those visitors become contacts, and how much those contacts are worth to you.

  • If your ads are focused on generating leads, you’ll want to see which ads are driving people’s first form submissions, how many of those contacts become customers, and how much those customers are worth to you

  • If your ads are focused on re-engaging existing contacts, you’ll want to see which contacts engaged, how many of those contacts become customers, and how much they are worth to you.

In the past, our tool has only focused on showing you how your ad campaigns are generating new contacts. This approach didn’t let you fully measure the success of your ad campaigns --- especially if you were running a retargeting campaign. With this update, you can now report on your ads success from a number of different vantage points, and see how your ads are influencing your contacts across every stage of their customer journey.

How does it work?

From the campaigns dashboard in the ads tool, you’ll now see an “Attribution Reports” drop down. This drop down will give you multiple options to filter your ad campaigns data, including:

  • First web session - ads that resulted in a visitors first web session.

  • Influenced first form submission - ads that a visitor clicked on before going on to submit a form

  • First form submission - ads that resulted in a visitor submitting a form in the same web session.

  • Re-engagement - ads your contact clicked on after becoming a contact.

Once a view is selected, the data on your campaigns dashboard will change to reflect the filter you’ve chosen. The contact, customer, revenue, etc. columns will all be based on the contacts associated with the ad campaign based on the ‘Attribution Report’ selection that you’ve made.

Who gets it?

Entry Question: Advanced Website Ads Audiences
Response:
What is it?

Last month, we let you get more granular with website audiences in the ads add-on by adding the ability to create audiences based on URL rules. Earlier this week we began rolling out expansions to this feature in several ways.

First, you can now target your ads based on interactions with specific content, such as a blog post. You can also create a website audience within a flexible time period to customize your targeting based on how recent a website interaction was. Finally, you can now combine multiple rules using ‘OR’ logic. All of these audiences can be created simultaneously across all advertising accounts and networks you have connected to HubSpot.

Why does it matter?

Website audiences allow you to retarget visitors to your site based on information you’ve gathered from their activity, allowing you to customize your ads based on their interests, their stage in the buyer’s journey, and the recency of their interactions. For example, if you have a set of blogs and landing pages all related to a similar topic, you can create an audience of anyone who has viewed any of those pages and retarget them with ads related to that topic. You can also, for example, create separate audiences of 1) visitors to your website within the last week and 2) visitors to your website within the last quarter. The more recent visitors are more likely to remember your brand and may be worth more to you, so you can adjust your content and your bidding strategy accordingly.

How does it work?

Within the ads tool, go to ‘Create audience’ and create a ‘Website visitors’ audience. Select your source pixel based on the specific account and advertising platform for which you wish to create the audience, and then choose which pages’ traffic you will target. When creating an audience off of traffic to a specific page, you now have a number of different options. You can create an audience of visitors to specific website pages, landing pages, or blog posts. You can still use ‘URL contains’ rules and you can now also use ‘URL equals’.

You can also include ‘OR’ rules to expand your audience. You could use this to target anyone who has visited your pricing page, or has visited your contact us page, for example.

Finally, you can now also edit the acceptable timeframe within which a visit happened in order for that site visitor to be included in your audience. If someone visited your pricing page for example, you might want to create an audience of anyone who visited that page within the last 7 days. For visitors to your blog, it might be better to have a longer timeframe for inclusion in your audience.

Entry Question: HubSpot Ads Privacy Policy Features
Response:
What is it?

HubSpot’s ads tool is now better aligned with GDPR. We’ve 1) linked the firing of your Facebook tracking pixel and/or your Google site tag to your HubSpot cookie consent banner, 2) made it so contacts deleted from HubSpot will be removed from any audiences (Facebook or Google) syncing to lists in HubSpot, and 3) we’ll sync lead ad consent fields over from Facebook automatically.

 

Why does it matter?

GDPR and other regulations are requiring businesses to give their contacts more control over their data.  As such, businesses need to be more transparent with how they collect customer data, and use that data to communicate with them. With this in mind, we’re making it easier for you to provide this transparency to your customers when advertising to them. With these updates, you’ll be able to more easily align your advertising with your data privacy policy to reach those contacts that want to hear from your brand.

   

How does it work?

If you have Facebook pixel code or Google’s site tag installed on your website, Facebook or Google may place a cookie on your site visitors. If you use the HubSpot ads tool to select and install your Facebook pixel or Google Site tag on pages with the HubSpot tracking code, we’ll seamlessly link the placing of that code to the HubSpot cookie notification banner (available in Settings > Reports & Analytics Tracking > Cookie Policy). This means that if you require opt-in consent via this banner, the Facebook pixel or Google site tag will not load in the visitor’s page until they have opted in.

 

Within the GDPR, a contact of yours has the right to request that you delete their data at any time. Now when you delete that contact in HubSpot, they will also be deleted from any syncing Facebook or Google ads audiences, ensuring that you no longer send advertisements to this contact.

 

Finally, any consent fields from your Facebook lead ads will now sync over to HubSpot as a new contact property. Each of these properties will be labeled with “FB Consent” at the beginning, making it easy for your to create lists of contacts who have actively given you consent to be contacted and bulk update their subscription type.

 

Who gets it?
The firing of your Facebook tracking pixel or your Google site tag along with your cookie banner, and lead syncing accounting for deleted contacts has been available for the past month or so now. We just released the lead ad consent field syncing feature, and now all three updates are available to all HubSpot users.

Entry Question: How Ads are Reported on in the Analytics Pipeline
Response:
Hey all - 

Want to respond to these questions to make sure this is clear for everyone (should also note that we're discouraged from replying-all to prod-notifies to save everyone's inboxes :-p)
 
Re Mariel's question: "Website Visitor X first finds website through the ad but does not convert on a form within 30 minutes. Their first touch in Analytics is PPC.
Visitor X then returns to the website by checking their history and this time, converts on a form within 30 minutes. Their last touch is NOT attributed to PPC, is that correct?"
 
This is correct. One clarification: a web session ends after 30 min of inactivity not after 30 min period. So if Visitor X clicked an ad, browsed around actively for an hour, and converted for the first time on a form, that ad would get attribution under the new logic.    
 
Re Sebastian's question: "So to my understanding the visualization on https://knowledge.hubspot.com/articles/kcs_article/reports/how-does-hubspot-calculate-conversions-in-the-ads-add-on is still correct?"
 
This illustration is still mostly correct. Under the new model, the conversion will need to happen in the web session originated by the ad for the ad to get credit for creating a new contact. This was not true before: in the old world, if you clicked an ad in January and then converted for the first time in September, the ad clicked in January would get credit for the conversion. We're working on updated knowledge docs to ensure this is clear. I've included a few examples below for understanding the distinction between Ads reporting and Traffic Analytics reporting.
    • Jane clicks a Facebook ad → clicks around ACME’s website → leaves → searches for related content a few days later → follows an organic search result to ACME’s landing page → fills out a form. 
      • In Ads, Jane’s click would not increase the number of “New Contacts” associated with the Facebook ad, since the source of the web session in which Jane converted into a contact (via the form) was organic search. Jane will have an ad event on her timeline and will appear in lists built to include all contacts who have interacted with this ad/campaign.
      • In Traffic Analytics, the number of “New Contacts” under Paid Social → Facebook would increase by one, since the source of Jane’s first web session was the Facebook ad.
    • Jane follows a link in a tweet → clicks around ACME’s website → leaves → searches for related content a few days later → clicks on an AdWords ad → lands on ACME’s landing page → fills out a form.
      • In Ads, Jane’s click would increase the number of “New Contacts” associated with the AdWords ad, since the ad was the source of the web session in which Jane convertedinto a contact (via the form). Jane will have an ad event on her timeline and will appear in lists built to include all contacts who have interacted with this ad/campaign.
      • In Traffic Analytics, the number of “New Contacts” under Paid Search would not increase by one, since the source of Jane’s first web session was a tweet. The number of“New Contacts” under Social Media → Twitter would increase by one.

 

Source: Email from Will DeKray to Product notifications

Entry Question: Ads is Moving to the Analytics Pipeline
Response:
What is it?

Ads is moving over to the Analytics Pipeline, improving the reliability with which we can attribute an ad to a contact’s conversion. As part of this, customers will see some of their ads data change.

 

Why does it matter?

Our current approach to attributing contacts to ads is messy and disjointed. We do not have a strict definition for how we attribute ads to contacts. This led to situations where ads were being credited for a conversion when a website visitor clicked an ad, did not interact with a customer’s content for quite some time (years in some cases), and then filled out a form later on after revisiting the site through organic search.

 

In the short term, today’s update gives greater reliability and accuracy to our reporting by creating a clear definition for how an ad is attributed to a contact. Down the road, we’ll be able to expand our definition of attribution to include ads that have influenced a contact during different stages of their journey to becoming a customer. This is the first step towards giving our users a more clear understanding of the success of their ads across the entire lifecycle of their contacts.  

 

How does it work?

The definition of how an ad is attributed to a contact is now being defined by “last touch.” To put it simply, an ad will be attributed to a new contact if it was the source of the web session in which that contact converted on a form. A customer can still get a sense of how successful their ads are at driving “first touch” interactions (an ad campaign and/or search term is the source of the contact’s first web session) by going to Traffic Analytics. Because we’re creating a more narrow definition of how a contact is attributed to an ad, customers can expect to see their analytics change.

 

To align the ads dashboard with our more explicit definition of attribution, we’ll be changing the “Leads” column to “New Contacts.”

 

Additionally, the ‘isConversion’ contact property for Facebook, Google Adwords, and LinkedIn Ads will no longer reflect the new analytics numbers. To ensure consistency across the whole tool, we will also be sunsetting this property. In the past, ads users who do remarketing campaigns have used this property to create lists of contacts that have interacted with an ad, but did not convert via that ad. Customers will still be able to create static lists from within the ads tool, or an active list of customers who have interacted with an ad campaign within the lists tool. They can further filter this list by whether or not the contact filled out a specific form to get similar information as they could with the ‘isConversion’ contact property.

 

Who gets it?

We’re currently in the process of rolling this out to all new customers. Towards the middle of April, we will begin ungating ads add-on users. A list of impacted portals can be found here. We will be reaching out to CSMs whose customers may be significantly impacted by this change prior to making the switch.

Entry Question: How does tracking work in the Ads Add-on?
Response:
Google Adwords:

HubSpot uses a tracking template that is inserted on the account level in Google Adwords. Assuming that there is no tracking applied on the Campaign, Adgroup, or Ad level, our template will be used by Google to fill in the tracking parameters. You can learn more about this here.

Here’s the template we use:

{lpurl}?ads_cmpid={campaignid}&ads_adid={adgroupid}&ads_matchtype={matchtype}&ads_network={network}&ads_creative={creative}&utm_term={keyword}&ads_targetid={targetid}&utm_campaign={_utmcampaign}&utm_source=adwords&utm_medium=ppc&ttv=2

The template incorporates utm_source, utm_medium, utm_campaign and utm_term so that all visits are correctly categorized in the Sources Report within HubSpot if a visit happens to be the visitor’s first interaction with you. This will bucket the visit under “Paid Search” as well as categorizing it by campaign and term.

The campaign parameter is set by custom parameters to correctly populate the utm_campaign on the Campaign level in Adwords. You can learn more about this here.

Entry Question: Unified “Do-No-Harm” Tracking Across all Ads in HubSpot
Response:
What is it?

We will now use the same tracking parameters across all ad networks supported within HubSpot. For AdWords, we will also merge our parameters with any existing parameters in customers’ account or campaign-level tracking templates. For Facebook, we will (continue to) merge our parameters with any existing parameters at the ad level.

 

Why does it matter?

In the old world, if you had your own parameters set up within AdWords in addition to HubSpot’s, we wouldn’t be able to handle this. If tracking was applied at the account level, HubSpot would overwrite any custom values with our values. If tracking was applied at the campaign level or lower, the ads would not be tracked in HubSpot. This was a major problem for users who wanted to track their ads in places other than HubSpot. In addition, we used to use separate tracking parameters for each network. This meant that the values accepted by the ads tool for tracking parameters of AdWords ads were different than the values accepted for Facebook ads. This led to a situation where each network had its own “counting” system, making it difficult to fully track your ads within HubSpot.

 

In this new world of ads tracking, we will merge our parameters with any existing AdWords parameters in customers’ account or campaign-level tracking templates. For Facebook, we will (continue to) merge our parameters with any existing parameters at the ad level. In addition, we will now use one set of tracking parameters across all supported ad networks. These changes simplify and unify the tracking used for ads within HubSpot.

 

How does it work?

In the near future, we will remove our old tracking parameters and apply our new set of tracking parameters to all ads except Facebook ads that have more than 20 engagements. Facebook adds tracking parameters to each individual ad, so editing the tracking parameters would reset Facebook’s ad optimization algorithm.

 

For AdWords, we are moving to campaign level tracking. Any tracking parameters you have set up within your AdWords tracking template at the campaign level or above will be merged with HubSpot’s tracking. It’s worth noting that if a customer has a tracking template at the group, ad, or keyword level, we will still be unable to appropriately track that ad because the templates at these lower levels will override the tracking we place at the campaign level.

 

Note: AdWords applies tracking parameters to the final destination URL for each ad. AdWords uses parameters from the “most specific” level that is populated (e.g., the ad level would be more specific than the campaign level). HubSpot needs these parameters to be populated in order to track the performance of ads. If the customer has parameters in the AdWords tracking template below the campaign level, HubSpot tracing will likely not function properly.

 

The following chart details how HubSpot will treat tracking parameters going forward. For a full rundown of how tracking works in the Ads add-on, feel free to refer to this knowledge doc.

 

Tracking Template Level - where tracking is applied

Treatment of parameters

Account

Merge HubSpot parameters with any existing parameters

Campaign

Merge HubSpot tracking with any existing parameters at the Campaign or Account level

Group

Any parameters the customer (or other tracking services) places at this level or below will override the templates at the above levels. This generally results in HubSpot being unable to track ads.

Ad

Any parameters the customer (or other tracking services) places at this level or below will override the templates at the above levels. This generally results in HubSpot being unable to track ads.

Keyword

Any parameters the customer (or other tracking services) places at this level or below will override the templates at the above levels. This generally results in HubSpot being unable to track ads.



Who gets it?

This is currently available to roughly 15% of customers, and we’ll be progressively rolling it out over the next week. This update will primarily impact Ads Add-on customers who make use of AdWords.

 

Sharing the news with customers

Feel free to share this product update blog post with any interested customers.

 

What language is it in?

All languages supported by HubSpot

Entry Question: Lead Ad Automation
Response:
What is it?

When creating or editing a Facebook lead ad within HubSpot, you’ll now have access to a number of new options. When creating a new lead ad, you’ll proceed through a wizard which includes a guided setup flow, and most importantly, the ability to automate follow up tasks for the leads that submit on your lead ads. You can also access these automation options by editing an existing lead ad.

 

Why does it matter?

Facebook lead ads are a quick and easy way to grow your list of leads within HubSpot. When clicking on them, users will be presented with a pre-filled form directly within Facebook --- all they have to do is press submit. This makes lead ads ideal for mobile conversion. In fact, HubSpot users are syncing over 800,000 leads from Facebook each month! The new lead ad experience not only makes it easier to create these lead ads, following a pattern that is familiar from other HubSpot tools, but it allows you to automate your follow up process and plan for next steps within your prospects buying journey. For example, you could use the automation options to create a smart list of contacts. That list could then be used as the audience for a different ad campaign. You could also enroll all contacts who fill out a lead ad into a workflow that will send a follow up email to these contacts.

 

How does it work?

Within the ads tool, create a Facebook lead ad. This will initiate a guided setup flow similar to the one used within the CTA Editor. In the first step, you’ll be asked to name your campaign. In the second step, you’ll create your lead ad within the Facebook popup modal, similar to how you always have. In the third and final step, you’ll be given the option to automate the lead ad.

 

From this screen, you’ll be able to select users you want to notify when you get a new contact, add these contacts to an active list, and also create a workflow that uses filling out that lead ad as its enrollment criteria.

 

Users of HubSpot’s free ads tools will see the option to edit any lead ad campaigns they created within HubSpot on the campaigns dashboard. Add-on users will see the option to edit any lead ad syncing with HubSpot by clicking down to the ad level.

 

Who gets it?

This is now available to all users of HubSpot’s ads tool, with different functionality depending on which version of the Marketing Hub you have. All users will receive access to lead ad notifications. Marketing Hub Basic, Professional, and Enterprise users will be able to add contacts who converted on a lead ad to an active list. Marketing Hub Professional and Enterprise users will be able to enroll contacts into a workflow.

Entry Question: Continuous Optimization for Lead Flows
Response:
What is it?

Maximize conversions by dynamically serving tailored lead flows to every visitor.

Why does it matter?

As marketers we’re always chasing after more. More visitors, more leads, and more customers. While the pursuit of more is admirable, it prioritizes revenue over relationships.

Driving more conversions doesn’t have to mean falling into the fallacy of growing at all costs. Today, with continuous optimization, you can now serve the best lead flow that is more likely to convert to every individual visitor based on all the web analytics and CRM data you have.

So, while a pop-up box may be best for some people, for others the dropdown banner may be preferred and ultimately convert at a higher rate.

How does it work?

When creating a lead flow, you’ll now see a new option called “Test out the types.”

When a user selects this option a machine learning algorithm will continuously test which of the four lead flow types works best for each visitor, based on behavioral and CRM data in their account.

There’s no manual setup required, and as continuous optimization is used more it will continue to learn and refine lead flows for better results.

Who gets it?

This is currently in a small private beta. If you have customers who are interested in continuous optimization, please fill out this form for them. As we progress we will expand the beta and add more customers. It will be live to all Marketing Hub Enterprise customers in January 2019.

Note: This is one of the first times we're scaling up our machine learning infrastructure to allow for every single customer to have their specific ML model. This means their recommendations and optimizations will be massively contextual to their business and customers. It also means we need to be careful and intentional with who we let enter the beta. As we get data from portals with a significant volume of traffic and conversions, we’ll start rolling this out to all Enterprise customers.

Entry Question: Changes to Default Behavior of Canonical URLs
Response:
What is it?

On January 8, 2018, we will be changing how HubSpot handles individual landing page, web page, and blog post canonical URLs by default. Going forward, we will no longer set a URL to self-canonicalize. Instead, there will be no canonical URL set, and customers will have the ability to edit the canonical URL of any blog post, landing page, or web page.

 

Why is it important?

A canonical URL is an HTML element used by search engines to handle duplicate content. Let’s say you have similar content on two different pages of your website. As Google crawls these pages, it will recognize the similarity of these pages, and your page SEO may take a hit as a result. A canonical URL tells search engines which piece of content is the preferred version, and prevents your site from being penalized for duplicate content. HubSpot previously defaulted to setting the Canonical URL of any page to itself. As Google and other search engines have gotten more sophisticated, self-canonicalizing a URL has become an outdated tactic. Today’s update allows users to manually edit the canonical URL of their pages, giving them more control over their site structure and SEO performance.   

 

How it works

When creating a blog post, landing page, or web page, click over to the Page Editor Settings tab. Under ‘Advanced Options,’ you’ll now see a new field that will allow you to set a customizable canonical URL for this page.

 

Some things that are important to note:

  • All content created before January 8th will still retain the self-canonical URL. If a user clicks into this field it will be editable.

  • All new content created after this release will have a blank value for canonical URL.

  • The ability to edit the canonical URL of a blog listing page is still in the works (stay tuned!)

 

Who gets it?

This change will go to all Marketing Basic, Professional, and Enterprise portals when the blog editor settings are Canvased on January 8th, 2018.
